item.title: 2 Samuel 1
item.description:
2 Samuel Chapter 1

1 After Saul died, David came back from massacring the Amalekites and stayed two days in Ziklag. 2The third day, a man came from Saul’s camp with torn clothes and dust on his head. He prostrated himself to David.

2 SAMUEL

3 David said, “Where have you come from?” “They’ve fled from the battle; many have fallen. Saul and his son Jonathan are dead.” 6"I happened to be on Mount Gilboa, and Saul was leaning on his spear. The chariots and cavalry were coming up on him. 7When he looked back, he called out to me, 8’Who are you?’ 10"So I stood beside him and killed him. I knew he couldn’t live. I took the crown off his head and the armband from his arm and brought them to you."

item.title: 2 Samuel 2
item.description:
2 Samuel Chapter 2

1 Afterwards David asked the LORD, “Should I go up to one of the towns in Judah?” David and his two wives went there. 3He brought his men up with their families, and they lived in towns around Hebron. 4Then the people in Judah came and anointed him king over Judah.

5 David sent them messengers, “The LORD bless you; you’ve been kind to Saul your lord and buried him. 6May the LORD show you enduring love and truth. I’ll also show you goodness for doing that. 7Be strong and brave. Your lord is dead, and Judah has anointed me king."

item.title: 2 Samuel 3
item.description:
2 Samuel Chapter 3

1 A long war had gone on between Saul and David. David had grown stronger; Saul had grown weaker.

2 David had six sons in Hebron: Amnon his oldest by Ahinoam the Jezreelitess, 3Chileab second by Abigail, the widow of Nabal of Carmel; Absalom third by Maacah daughter of Tahmai, king of Geshur; 4 Adonijah fourth by Haggith, Shephatiah fifth by Abital, 5and Ithream sixth by Eglah.

item.title: 2 Samuel 4
item.description:
2 Samuel Chapter 4

1 When Ish-bosheth heard that Abner had died in Hebron, his courage failed, and Israel lost courage too. 2Saul’s son had two men that were commanding raiding bands: Baanah and Rechab, sons of Rimmon, a Benjamite from Beeroth (considered part of Benjamin). 3The people of Beeroth fled to Gittaim and still live there as foreigners.

4 Jonathan had a son Mephibosheth that was lame in both feet. He was five when the news about Saul and Jonathan arrived from Jezreel. His nurse picked him up and fled. As she hurried, he fell and became lame.

item.title: 2 Samuel 5
item.description:
2 Samuel Chapter 5

1 All the tribes came to David in Hebron and said, “We’re your flesh and bones. 2When Saul was king, you were the one that led Israel out and back. The LORD told you you’d shepherd his people."

3 Israel’s elders came, and King David made a treaty with them in the LORD’s presence. They anointed him king over Israel. 4David was 30 and ruled for 40 years. 5He ruled Judah for 7½ years in Hebron and ruled Judah and Israel for 33 years in Jerusalem.

item.title: 2 Samuel 6
item.description:
2 Samuel Chapter 6

1 David gathered elite troops from Israel again, 30,000. 2He and the troops went to Baale-judah to bring up God’s Ark called The Name: the LORD of Hosts Enthroned Above the Cherubs. 3They placed the Ark on a new cart to bring it from Abinadab’s house that was on the hill. Uzzah and Ahio, Abinadab’s sons, 4were bringing the Ark on the cart; Ahio was walking ahead of it. 5Meanwhile, David and the House of Israel were celebrating enthusiastically in the LORD’s presence with all kinds of instruments made out of fir: lyres, harps, tambourines, castanets, and cymbals.

item.title: 2 Samuel 7
item.description:
2 Samuel Chapter 7

1 The king was living in his palace, and the LORD had given him rest from his enemies. 2He told Nathan the prophet, “I live in a cedar palace, but God’s Ark sits in tent curtains."

3 Nathan said, “Do everything you’re thinking; the LORD’s with you."

4 But that night a message from the LORD came to him, 5"Go tell my servant David, ‘The LORD says, “Are you the one that should build me a temple? 6I haven’t lived in a temple since I brought Israel out of Egypt. I’ve moved around in a tent, a Tabernacle. 7Wherever I’ve gone with Israel, did I ever say to any judge that I commanded to shepherd my people, ‘Why haven’t you built me a cedar temple?’”’ 8"Tell David, ‘I took you out of the pasture from following sheep, to make you ruler over Israel. 9I’ve been with you wherever you’ve gone and got rid of your enemies. I’ll make you as famous as anyone that’s ever lived in the world. 10I’ll appoint a place to plant my people so they can live there undisturbed, and sinful people won’t oppress them anymore. 11Like when I appointed judges over them, I’ll give you rest from your enemies.’ “The LORD also says he’ll make a dynasty from you. 12-13’When you die, I’ll raise up your descendant and establish his kingdom permanently. 13He’ll build me a temple. 14I’ll be his father, and he’ll be my son. When he sins, I’ll correct him with rods like people do. 15But my enduring love won’t leave him like it did Saul, that I removed before you. 16Your family and kingdom will endure. I’ll establish your dynasty permanently.’"

item.title: 2 Samuel 8
item.description:
2 Samuel Chapter 8

1 After that, David defeated the Philistines and took Methegammah.

2 He defeated Moab and counted them off in lines and made them lie down on the ground. Two lines he counted off to be put to death, and one line he let live. The Moabites served him and brought tribute.

3 David also defeated Hadadezer son of Rehob, king of Zobah, as he went to restore his power at the Euphrates River. 4He took 1,700 cavalry and 20,000 infantry. He hamstrung the chariot horses but left enough for 100 chariots.

item.title: 2 Samuel 9
item.description:
2 Samuel Chapter 9

1 Then David asked if anybody was left from Saul’s house that he could show kindness out of regard for Jonathan. 2There was a servant named Ziba. They called him to David, and the king said, “You are Ziba?"

5 David had him brought in. 6He came and prostrated himself. David said, “Mephibosheth, 7you don’t have to be afraid. I’ll treat you well out of regard for your father Jonathan, and give you back the land that belonged to your grandfather Saul; you’ll eat at my table regularly."

item.title: 2 Samuel 10
item.description:
2 Samuel Chapter 10

1 The king of the Ammonites died, and his son Hanun became king. 2David said, “I’ll be kind to Hanun son of Nahash like his father was kind to me.” David sent some ambassadors to console him about his father. But when they got there, 3the Ammonite officials said to Hanun, “Do you think David is honoring your father because he sent consolers? Hasn’t he sent them to look over the city, spy it out, and overthrow it?” 4Hanun took David’s ambassadors and shaved off half their beards, cut off their cloaks as high as their hips, and sent them away. 5When David found out, he sent to meet them because they were really humiliated. He told them to stay at Jericho till their beards grew, and then come back.

item.title: 2 Samuel 11
item.description:
2 Samuel Chapter 11

1 In the spring when kings normally go to war, David sent Joab and Israel’s army to destroy the Ammonites and lay siege to Rabbah. David stayed in Jerusalem.

2 When evening came, David got up from his bed and walked around on the roof of his palace. From the roof he saw a woman taking a bath; she was beautiful. 3David sent and asked about her. Someone said, “Isn’t this Bathsheba, daughter of Eliam, wife of Uriah the Hittite?” 4David sent messengers and took her. When she came to him, he slept with her. When she’d purified herself, she went home. 5She got pregnant and sent and told David.

item.title: 2 Samuel 12
item.description:
2 Samuel Chapter 12

1 Then the LORD sent Nathan to David to say, “Two men were in a town, one rich, the other poor. 2The rich man had lots of flocks and herds, 3but the poor man had nothing but one little ewe lamb that he’d bought and raised. It grew up with him and his children; it used to eat his bread and drink from his cup and lie in his lap; it was like a daughter to him. 4A traveler came to the rich man, and he wasn’t willing to take one of his own flock or herd to fix a meal for him. He took the poor man’s lamb and fixed it.” David was mad, and swore to Nathan, “As sure as the LORD lives, that man deserves to die. 6He’ll restore the lamb fourfold because he did that without mercy."

item.title: 2 Samuel 13
item.description:
2 Samuel Chapter 13

1 David’s son Absalom had a beautiful sister named Tamar, and David’s son Ammon was in love with her. 2Amnon was so frustrated because of his sister that he made himself ill, because she was a virgin and it seemed hard to do anything to her. 3But Amnon had a friend Jonadab son of Shimeah, David’s brother, and Jonadab was a shrewd fellow.

4 He said to him, “Son of the king, why are you so depressed morning after morning? Won’t you tell me?

item.title: 2 Samuel 14
item.description:
2 Samuel Chapter 14

1 Joab sensed that the king yearned for Absalom. 2So he sent to Tekoa and brought a wise woman, and told her, “Act like you’re in mourning. Put on mourning clothes, don’t anoint yourself with oil. Act like a woman that’s been mourning for the dead for many days. 3Then go to the king and say such and such."

4 When she spoke to the king, she fell on her face and said, “Help me, my king.” “I’m a widow; my husband’s dead. 6I had two sons, but they quarreled in the field, and no one was there to separate them. One struck the other and killed him. 7Now the whole family has risen up and told me to hand over the one that struck his brother so they can put him to death for the life of his brother, and destroy the heir too. They’ll put out my ember that’s left and won’t leave my husband a name or a remnant."

item.title: 2 Samuel 15
item.description:
2 Samuel Chapter 15

1 After that, Absalom provided himself a chariot, horses, and 50 men to run ahead of him. 2He’d get up early and stand by the road to the gate. When anybody had a suit to come to the king for judgment, Absalom would call to him and say,

3 Then Absalom would say, “Your claims are right, but everybody with the king is ignoring you. 4If only somebody would appoint me judge in the land, everyone that has a suit could come to me for justice."

item.title: 2 Samuel 16
item.description:
2 Samuel Chapter 16

1 When David had gone a little past the summit, Ziba, Mephibosheth’s steward, met him with a couple saddled donkeys. They were carrying 200 loaves of bread, 100 clusters of raisins, 100 summer fruits, and a skin of wine.

2 The king asked, “Why do you have these?” “The donkeys are for the king’s family to ride. The bread and summer fruit are for the young men to eat. The wine is for anybody to drink that’s become exhausted in the country."

item.title: 2 Samuel 17
item.description:
2 Samuel Chapter 17

1 In addition, Ahithophel told Absalom, “Let me choose 12,000 men to pursue David tonight. 2I’ll attack him while he’s exhausted and terrify him. The people with him will run. I’ll only strike down the king 3and bring the people back to you. Everybody’s return depends on the man you’re looking for. Then the people will be at peace."

4 The plan pleased Absalom and Israel’s elders.

item.title: 2 Samuel 18
item.description:
2 Samuel Chapter 18

1 Then David counted his people and set over them commanders of thousands and hundreds. 2He sent out the troops, a third each under Joab, Abishai, and Ittai. He told them, “I’ll go out with you too."

3 They said, “You shouldn’t go out. If we flee, they won’t care even if half of us die. You’re worth 10,000 of us. It’s better for you to be ready to help us from town."

item.title: 2 Samuel 19
item.description:
2 Samuel Chapter 19

1 Then Joab heard, “The king is crying and mourning for Absalom.” 2The victory that day turned into mourning because those who heard about it said, “The king is grieving for his son.” 3So the people slipped into the city like humiliated people sneak away from battle. 4The king covered his face and cried out, “Absalom! My son! My son!"

5 Then Joab went into the house and told the king, “You’ve shamed your men today. They’ve saved your life, the lives of your sons and daughters, your wives and concubines. 6By loving the ones that hate you and hating the ones that love you, you’ve shown that officers and troops don’t mean anything to you. If Absalom was alive and all of us dead, you’d be pleased. 7Get up; go speak graciously to them. I swear by the LORD, if you don’t, not a man will spend the night with you. This will be worse than all the bad things that have come on you since you were young."

item.title: 2 Samuel 20
item.description:
2 Samuel Chapter 20

1 A troublemaker happened to be there—Sheba son of Bicri, a Benjamite. He blew the ram’s horn and said,

2 The men from Israel deserted David and followed Sheba. But Judah stayed firmly committed to their king and escorted him from the Jordan to Jerusalem.

3 David went to his palace in Jerusalem. The ten concubines he’d left behind to keep the house, he put under guard and took care of them; but didn’t have relations with them. They like widows till they died.

item.title: 2 Samuel 21
item.description:
2 Samuel Chapter 21

1 In David’s time, a famine came that lasted three years. He sought the LORD. The LORD said, “It’s because Saul and his bloody family murdered the people in Gibeon.” 2 (The inhabitants of Gibeon weren’t part of Israel but a remnant of the Amorites. The Israelites had made a treaty with them, but Saul had intended to kill them off in his zeal for Israel and Judah.) The king called them, 4"It’s not a matter of silver or gold between us and Saul or his family. It’s not for us to put anybody to death in Israel."

item.title: 2 Samuel 22
item.description:
2 Samuel Chapter 22

1 David sang this song to the LORD when he delivered him from his enemies and from Saul:

4 I called on him who deserves praise,

5 The waves of death entangled me;

7 In my desperation I cried out to the LORD,

8 Then the earth quaked and the mountains shook

9 Smoke poured out of his nostrils;

10 He lowered the sky too

11 He rode on a cherub

item.title: 2 Samuel 23
item.description:
2 Samuel Chapter 23

1 David’s last words

3 The God of Israel said,

5 Is not my family that way with God?

6 But godless people every one will be thrown aside like briers,

7 If you touch them,

8 These are David’s most elite soldiers: Josheb-basshebeth, a Tahchemonite [a Hachmonite in 1 Chronicles 11:11], chief of The Three. He was called Adino the Eznite because he killed 800 men in one battle.

item.title: 2 Samuel 24
item.description:
2 Samuel Chapter 24

1 Again the LORD’s anger burned against Israel, and he aroused David to count the people in Israel and Judah.

2 The king told Joab the commander of the army, “Go through the tribes from Dan to Beersheba, and register the people so I can know how many there are."

3 But Joab said, “May the LORD your God multiply the people 100 times while you can still see it, but why delight in this?"
